Document Sources.Sourced Statement: In December 2020, the city and Southwest signed a settlement in which, among other things, the airline agreed to fully restore the sick leave hours it had canceled for certain workers between 2017 and 2020.
Document Sources.Source Justification: The lawsuit — filed just a couple days after Labor Day—claims that Southwest has also violated an existing settlement agreement that was supposed to resolve similar problems.

Document Sources.Sourced Statement: According to the city attorney, Southwest didn’t restore those hours for all workers.
Document Sources.Source Justification: The lawsuit — filed just a couple days after Labor Day—claims that Southwest has also violated an existing settlement agreement that was supposed to resolve similar problems.

Named Person Sources.Sourced Statement: “The City of Oakland is committed to protecting workers by ensuring that all employers in Oakland are complying with laws that protect their rights,” Parker said in a statement.
Named Person Sources.Source Justification: On Wednesday, City Attorney Barbara Parker filed a lawsuit in Alameda County Superior Court that accuses the airline of violating Oakland and California sick leave laws.

Named Person Sources.Sourced Statement: “Southwest Airlines fully complies with applicable sick leave laws in Oakland and California, as well as with the terms of a December 2020 settlement agreement with the city,” the spokesperson said in a statement.
Named Person Sources.Source Justification: A Southwest spokesperson told The Oaklandside that the assertion that any Oakland employee was forced to work while sick or take unpaid absences is unfounded.

Named Person Sources.Sourced Statement: “We are grateful that the City of Oakland is holding Southwest accountable. We hope that Southwest policies and practices will finally change for good,” Eric Swygert, a Southwest employee and an elected ramp representative with the Transport Workers Union of America Local 555, said in a statement.
Named Person Sources.Source Justification: Eric Swygert, a Southwest employee and an elected ramp representative with the Transport Workers Union of America Local 555, said in a statement.

Named Organization Sources.Sourced Statement: On Wednesday, City Attorney Barbara Parker filed a lawsuit in Alameda County Superior Court that accuses the airline of violating Oakland and California sick leave laws.
Named Organization Sources.Source Justification: Oakland is suing Southwest Airlines for allegedly depriving its workers paid sick leave, and for breaching a 2020 settlement over the same issue.

Named Organization Sources.Sourced Statement: The city is demanding that Southwest comply with local labor laws and the 2020 settlement agreement; pay restitution, damages and penalties to the affected workers; pay for the cost of the city enforcing the law; and undo any disciplinary actions taken against workers under the allegedly unlawful sick leave policy.
Named Organization Sources.Source Justification: Oakland is suing Southwest Airlines for allegedly depriving its workers paid sick leave, and for breaching a 2020 settlement over the same issue.

Named Organization Sources.Sourced Statement: “Although Southwest remains willing to address the city’s concerns about sick leave policies, the airline is prepared to vigorously defend itself against these frivolous claims in court, including by asking the court to address the city’s own breach of the settlement agreement.”
Named Organization Sources.Source Justification: A Southwest spokesperson told The Oaklandside that the assertion that any Oakland employee was forced to work while sick or take unpaid absences is unfounded.
